importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the previous government shutdown, which lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years.
The end date of the 2018 government shutdown, marking the conclusion of the longest shutdown in history.
The date of the latest update on the current government shutdown, indicating ongoing disruption in federal operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the longest government shutdown in history, lasting 35 days.
The current full government shutdown, caused by failure to pass 12 appropriations bills, with no funding agreement reached as of the article's update.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown in history, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, lasted 35 days and was the longest in nearly 50 years.
The 2018 shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
During the 2018 shutdown, about 800,000 federal employees were affected, with approximately 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay but required to report to work.
The current government shutdown is a full shutdown, as no 12 appropriations bills have been passed by Congress.
Government shutdowns have become less frequent since 1990 but remain politically volatile due to partisanship and procedural barriers like Senate filibusters.
Republican Speaker Mike Johnson oversees a narrow House majority, and the GOP lacks 60 Senate votes to end a filibuster, making bipartisan negotiations difficult.
A partial shutdown (where only some agencies operate) was seen in 2018, while the current situation is a full shutdown affecting all federal operations.
Federal employees in furloughed agencies receive backpay when operations resume.

namedEntities.name: United States federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national government of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central subject of the article, as the article details the current and past shutdowns of its operations.

namedEntities.name: December 22, 2018
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specific date marking the start of a government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It marks the beginning of the longest government shutdown in history, serving as a key reference point.

namedEntities.name: January 25, 2019
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specific date marking the end of a government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It marks the conclusion of the 35-day shutdown, the longest in nearly 50 years.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. government agency that analyzes the economic impact of policy decisions
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CBO provided an estimate of $3 billion in lost GDP from the 2018 shutdown, adding economic context to the event.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He oversees a narrow House majority, contributing to political challenges in passing spending legislation and avoiding shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A procedural rule in the U.S. Senate that allows extended debate to block passage of legislation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It creates a major obstacle for the GOP, which lacks 60 votes to overcome, thereby delaying funding agreements.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 federal employees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of people affected during the 2018 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights the human impact of government shutdowns, with 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempted from pay.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A set of bills required to fund different federal departments
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to pass all 12 bills is the direct cause of the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Gillian Roberts and Kaanita Iyer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CNN reporters who authored the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are the source of the reporting and provide credibility to the article's content.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing public awareness about government shutdowns and their consequences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details the ongoing full government shutdown in the United States, emphasizing that it is the first such event in a prolonged period without a spending agreement. It references the previous 2018 shutdown as the longest in nearly 50 years, lasting 35 days and costing an estimated $3 billion in GDP. The article explains that during that period, around 800,000 federal employees were affected, with 300,000 furloughed and others exempted from pay. The current shutdown, caused by Congress failing to pass 12 appropriations bills, is a full shutdown affecting all federal operations. Political obstacles, such as the lack of a Senate majority to end a filibuster and a narrow House majority under Speaker Mike Johnson, have made negotiations difficult. The article underscores the economic and societal consequences of such events, including lost productivity and employee disruption, and highlights the role of partisan division in prolonging funding gaps.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
